subject: Re: [junit] Parameterisation of tests in JUnit4

messageBody:
Jon Skeet wrote:

> I've had a look at the Parameterized runner in JUnit4 (current CVS) and
> I have a few suggestions.

Jon,

Thanks a lot for the suggestions. I worked with Kent and Erich on the
parameterized support, so here's my utterly non-binding thoughts:

In general, I'm a fan of the Kent and Erich's plan to keep JUnit 4.0 as
simple as possible, while still allowing impressive amounts of
extension. To that end, it would be great to have a third party work on
a souped-up parameterized test runner with features like you mention here.

I wrote a separate runner a while back that parameterizes tests by
method, but felt ambivalent about it--it was very different from how
parameterized tests had been done in JUnit 3, and I hadn't really wanted
it yet in my own development, so I wasn't sure I'd gotten it "right",
and I didn't submit it to Kent. However, you're not the first to
request it. In any case, do you really want to have parameters on both
the class and the methods? That seems really complex.

> // In actual code, these would probably be enums, in my
> experience -
> // they would provide mechanisms for connecting to the
> appropriate database,
> // setting it up and tearing it down etc.
> public static String[] classParameters = {"Oracle", "SQL"};

Using an enum to contain the parameters is a cool idea. Would it be
much easier than
@Parameters public static List<DbType> parameters() { return
DbType.values() }?

> @Test
> @Parameters(strings={"hello", "there"})
> public void test3(String input)
> {
> assertEquals(input, input.toLowerCase());
> }

I like that a lot.

> 2) Unless multiple parameters are required, a single array (rather than
> an array of arrays) causes less confusion. I know that the
> counter-argument to that is that having two forms, one for
> single-parameter tests/constructors and one for multi-parameter
> tests/constructors is ugly, but I personally believe that it's justified
> in this case.

I like your case here.

For the rest of your features, I think they're cool. I'd like to see a
runner that did them, and play with it a while.

> 5) One nasty problem: you need to construct instances of the test class
> just to count the test cases - and hope that the parameters you get back
> then is the same as the ones you get when you're ready to run the tests.
> (You could cache the results, of course...)

That's a rough problem. In general, I think that runners should avoid
constructing instances in order to count test cases. Do you think it's
worth it?

> Anyway, the bottom line is that I can see *huge* benefits in this
> approach in quite a few of our existing test code. Does anyone have any
> major objections to the above, or shall I give it a whirl?

Absolutely give it a whirl.

David Saff
